author: MATT YOUNG
title: Whitney Houston stalker fan letters unearthed by FBI |
text:
HANDWRITTEN letters from a “loner” fan to Whitney Houston posted 27 years ago reveal the terrifying downside of fame.
Written during the height of the late singer’s fame, the letters contain chilling lines such as “I am afraid of what I might do.”
Unsealed to the public by the FBI, the 128-page document chronicles the fan’s drastic attempts to contact Houston, with each letter becoming more and more desperate for a response. So extreme were his notes, the FBI initially believed the letters were an extortion attempt.
“I have gotten that desperate and that mad and would come up with ideas that ... it scares me that I might come up with some crazy or really dumb idea,” he writes.
“I might hurt someone with some crazy idea and not realise how stupid an idea is until after I have done it. That really scares me.”
In almost a year and a half, the unidentified fan sent 66 letters to Houston and a further 10 more to representatives of the star, including Houston’s father. All went unanswered.
“Many times when I think about you I will start to shake. Miss Whitney, what am I doing wrong? I am in love with you. I really and truly am in love with you. Whitney, please, please give me a chance.”
Houston eventually contacted the FBI for help.
The golden days: Whitney Houston in 1987. Picture: David McGough Inc. Entertainment Source: News Corp Australia
”I am getting very desperate”. Source: Supplied
”You are a beautiful lady and a beautiful person”. Source: Supplied
“Upon [blank] receiving the letter and determining its contents contained vague and non-specific threats, [blank] became concerned with Houston’s wellbeing,” reads the 1988 FBI report.
Much of the FBI report on the case remains redacted, including the identity of the fan except for his hometown of Vermont, in northeast U.S.
In an interview with the FBI at a later date, he was described as 170cm, 65 kilograms with brown hair and brown eyes. He was unemployed at the time but had served with the US Army.
His letters, postmarked Burlington, Vermont, tell a different story.
“I am not a love struck kid,” he defends.
“I am 28 years old, a former combat engineer sergeant and I am now a political activist”.
He writes how he first fell in love with Houston in March 1986, the month she released The Greatest Love of All .
“Miss Whitney, you are a beautiful lady and a beautiful person.
“I really and truly am in love with you.”
”Why can’t you respond to my 70-plus letters?” Source: Supplied
”You probably think I’m crazy. Well maybe I am”. Source: Supplied
In another letter, the fan pleads with a close aide to Houston, explaining his desire for the singer to receive his letters expressing his undying love.
“When I first fell in love with Miss Whitney I tried to ignore what I felt towards her,” he writes.
“After 5 months I had to do something and so I started writing letters. I have tried to stop writing the letters and to give up twice but after a few weeks I had to start writing again. I just have to keep trying.
“I have tried to forget what I feel towards her a few times. I have gotten mad at her a few times, a few of the letters have not been very nice. I have gotten so mad and desperate.”
He describes himself as “sort of a loner” who is “not very good with people.”
He explains he has been to nine of Houston’s concerts “and have tried to give her flowers twice. Miss Whitney is the first lady that I have ever given flowers to”.
“When I think about you I will start to shake”. Source: Supplied
“I almost broke down”. Source: Supplied
In another letter, he describes how he “almost broke down” when he read a tabloid suggesting Houston was married.
“I am sure they made it up ... I have been sick for the last several days. I cannot stop thinking about it and I just shake and feel sick in my gut.
“You probably think I am crazy. Well, meebe (sic) I am. I just can’t give up. I have to keep trying. I really am in love with you.”
On June 8, 1988, after the 79th letter to Houston — including six to her father and a further 16 to family acquaintances — the FBI finally knocked on the man’s door to find a “small, cluttered one-room apartment”.
“He advised that he had no intention of threatening Houston or anyone else with physical harm,” the report reads.
”In conversation with [blank] it was apparent that he is obsessed with Whitney Houston.
“He did not appear to interact well socially with the interviewing Agent in that he was very uncomfortable.
The FBI eventually concluded, “based on the facts presented” the fan “did not constitute a violation of Federal Law”.
And with that, the case was closed.
A copy of one of the envelopes addressed to Whitney Houston. Source: Supplied
Originally published as The terrifying downside of fame
